ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Jot, RNA and ReST vs MoST
ygData.msgSnippet: Seairth and Bill, The genius of ReST is its recognition of the value of a standardized resource interface in a heterogeneous large scale networked environments

Seairth and Bill,

The genius of ReST is its recognition of the value of a standardized 
resource interface in a heterogeneous large scale networked environments 
and its attempt to articulate such an interface.  Its tragic flaw is that 
it did not standardize enough of the *semantics* of this interface to 
achieve the value it promised.  To be perfectly clear about the problem:

* Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server maps the state of a 
resource into a response to a GET request, a client can have ABSOLUTELY NO 
IDEA what the content of that response means; it is simply has bits that 
can mean anything at all.

* Without an *explicit* model of exactly how the server uses PUT/POST-ed 
content to change the state of a resource, a client can have ABSOLUTELY NO 
IDEA what the effect of a PUT or POST actually will be.

Roy thinks these explicit models should be entirely arbitrary and specified 
at the whim of the server operator on a per-URI basis.  I think these 
models should be standardized in some manner and be URI independent.

This conflict stems from different views of the nature of an HTTP resource 
itself.  Roy says:
"""
Any information that can be named can be a resource: a document or image, a 
temporal service (e.g. "today's weather in Los Angeles"), a collection of 
other resources, a non-virtual object (e.g. a person), and so on. In other 
words, any concept that might be the target of an author's hypertext 
reference must fit within the definition of a resource.
"""

Because Roy's resources are so abstract, access to them has to be mediated 
by agents of arbitrary power and complexity.  Allowing clients to interact 
with agents of this power and complexity through HTTP then requires that 
service operators be permitted to overload HTTP methods to have essentially 
arbitrary meanings.

But resources don't really need to be so abstract and the meanings of HTTP 
methods don't need to be so loose.  Programs don't actually manipulate 
"concepts" or "non-virtual objects;" they just manipulate bits.  It would 
be more realistic to say that an HTTP resource is simply a set of bits 
whose syntactic structure is enforced by an HTTP server and whose meaning 
is determined entirely by agents which interact with this server.  To say 
otherwise is to say that there is a meaningful difference in effect between 
having an agent poll a resource and act when it changes and having a server 
notify an agent to act whenever a resource is changed or to say that there 
is a meaningful difference between such an agent residing on the HTTP 
server itself and such an agent residing on another machine across the 
Internet and interacting via HTTP.

Viewed this way, it makes no sense to talk about some single *special* 
hidden representation to which a single special HTTP server agent mediates 
access.  Instead we should recognize that agents on the server and across 
the Internet can use any data structures they want for their activities but 
that their doing so is really beside the point.  The function of an HTTP 
server as such is simply to provide a shared blackboard for communication 
between these agents.  What these agents really need is a shared *explicit 
model* for determining what is on this blackboard and for how it may be 
changed.

Thanks to Roy and ReST we know the basic operations we need.  GET is a 
retrieval of whatever is on the universal blackboard at a particular 
location.  PUT replaces what is on the blackboard at that location.  DELETE 
erases it.  POST adds to it.  But we also need a shared *explicit model* of 
exactly how these operations work.  That project of defining these 
*explicit models* is what I am promoting under the name, MoST.

-Alex-

PS Bill, I have heard of speech acts, but I don't know how they apply here.

___________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media
1-212-787-1914 voice                    1-603-288-1280 fax

--On Tuesday, August 05, 2003 8:26 PM -0400 Seairth Jacobs 
<seairth@...> wrote:

> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>>
> <deleted>
>
> Okay.  I really must not be grasping what you are saying about REST vs
> MoST. It seems to me that MoST is just an additional layer above ReST,
> but you appearently believe the two architectures are dissimilar.  When
> you get a working model of this MoST approach up, I would certainly like
> to see more. Until then, I think the REST approach provides good
> guidelines that have significantly improved (and are continuing to
> improve) the design of my applications.  If you can offer something
> better, I'm all ears.  But at this point, I just don't see what you seem
> to see.
